abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Liberia Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project for Liberia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            was moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: the procurement lessons learned in
            the International Competitive Bidding (ICB) for works and
            large value consulting contracts for post-conflict
            environments are finding interested contractors and
            consultants with adequate capacity and experience to work in
            a fragile state; engineering estimates for critical works
            and installations in post-conflict countries, especially
            those to be bid under ICB, should appreciate, recognize and
            accommodate the influence of potential bidders'
            perceived risks and uncertainties in the post-conflict
            environment, in order to provide realistic working estimates
            for critical post conflict infrastructure to facilitate
            effective budgeting; and there is need for early
            identification of qualified firms in the market, relative to
            required specialized and or critical services and engage
            their interest. Wherever possible, consider an amalgamation
            of resources into one sizeable project. Project design
            lessons learned are: it is important not to design projects
            that are overambitious in scope, since this may lead to
            critical activities not being implemented by others and
            increasing risks in a fragile situation. A well laid out
            structure for institutional collaboration in a
            well-coordinated manner for all project activities is
            fundamental to effective implementation of such projects,
            especially for multiple stakeholders. Supervision of
            specialist assignments should not be entrusted to a
            governmental unit until it has demonstrated previously that
            it is capable of handling the task. Extraordinary efforts
            need to be made to attract contractors and consultants to a
            country during the project preparation phase. Timely
            oversight mechanism and support is extremely necessary in a
            post-conflict environment where the circumstances are fast
            changing and evolving, particularly, on problems
            identification and early reporting by the technical staff
            during implementation.

17517488.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Liberia - Infrastructure Rehabilitation
            Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Liberian
            Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (LIRP), is to provide
            the Government with emergency support to restore priority
            infrastructure in the Port of Monrovia and at Roberts
            International Airport and assist the Government in
            developing a medium-term strategic framework for
            rehabilitating the port and aviation sectors. Negative
            measures include: air pollution, noise pollution, water
            pollution, solid waste generation, and impacts on flora and
            fauna. Mitigation measures include:  (a) use of good quality
            fuel and lubricants; (b) prevention of dust through
            sprinkling during periods of dry season; (c) noise
            prevention measures, such as mufflers, installed on vehicles
            and equipment; (d) tanks for fuel storages should be leak
            proof and installed in a bunded area, fuel storage tanks
            shall be checked daily, and in case of leakage will be
            replaced until repaired; (e) excavated soils should be
            reused as much as possible as filling material, and
            contaminated soil should be considered as waste material and
            disposed of accordingly. Excess soil should be disposed off
            at sites approved by the municipality; and (f) the
            contractor should minimize the destruction of flora and
            limit the working area to prevent unnecessary ecological damages.

8601550.trustfund:
TF030807-JAPAN CTF - FY06 GENERAL: GENERAL,TF057072-LIBERIA INFRASTRUCTURE
            REHABILITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The project, development objective of
            the Liberian Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (LIRP),
            is to provide Government with emergency support to restore
            priority infrastructure in the Port of Monrovia and at
            Roberts International Airport and assist the Government in
            developing a medium-term strategic framework for
            rehabilitating the port and aviation sectors. Successful
            implementation of the project will be evidenced by: (a)
            identified civil works implemented; (b) institutional
            capacity strengthened; and (c) Government has developed a
            strategic framework for port and aviation sector. There are
            three components to the project: (1) infrastructure
            rehabilitation in which the Technical Assessment Report o f
            Emergency and Longer Term Actions required in the Port of
            Monrovia lists some 25 different projects identified through
            detailed discussions and workshops with the National Port
            Authority (NPA) and stakeholders; (2) technical assistance
            and capacity building to provide selective and ad-hoc
            technical assistance to Government, including support to
            develop a strategic framework for the sub-sectors, as well
            as targeted training in NPA and Roberts International
            Airport (RIA) to complement normalization of operations; and
            (c) project management to implement overall responsibility
            by the Ministry o f Public Works through a Special
            Implementation Unit (SIU) being set up and which will
            provide coordination, procurement, M&E and support to
            safeguard management.
